image.name: S000210_001

profileText: A Delegate from Pennsylvania; born in New York City in 1730; completed preparatory studies; engaged in business at Madeira in 1757; moved to Philadelphia, Pa., in 1762; one of the managers of the United States lottery 1776-1778; member of the Navy board in 1778; Member of the Continental Congress 1778-1780; trustee of the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia 1779-1781; was commissioner to France and Holland to negotiate a loan for the state of Pennsylvania 1780-1782, but was unsuccessful; located in New York City in 1784 as agent for an importing house; returned to Pennsylvania in 1785; died in Philadelphia, Pa., on August 7, 1797; interment in St. Peter's Churchyard.

asset.name: S000210_001
asset.creditLine: Image courtesy of the New York Public Library

researchRecord.name: 1781, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Searle to Monsieur written on June 2, 1781. In the letter, James Searle invites Monsieur Dumas for a visit.

researchRecord.name: 1790, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James Searle to John de Neufville written on April 8, 1790. In the letter, James Searle discusses money which he has lent to John de Neufville, and proposes some financial arrangements which John de Neufville might find convenient.

researchRecord.name: In the American Lottery Tickets Collection, 1761-1826, 0.2 linear foot.
